author: frozenfire.eth
content:
<@360491619402776577> Regarding letting full nodes act as KZG setup ceremony contributors, that would be beneficial in the sense of having +1 setup clients.

It would be extra beneficial if the nodes could publicly commit (maybe in a block they produce?) to their contribution transcript, and later publicly verify that their transcript is part of the final setup.

author: frozenfire.eth
content: But, my understanding of trusted setups is that it's more important to have many different, fully independent implementations of the contribution client, than to have many contributions.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Can we aggregate contributions together before adding them to the setup?
E.g. I want to aggregate all of my friends contributions into one that I am going to use for the ceremony, so I am only taking up one slot in the public ceremony but have multiple more contributions (that trust me to some extend)

author: frozenfire.eth
content: I imagine that you could produce an MPC scheme for generating the contribution, where each party has a share of the contribution secret.

author: frozenfire.eth
content: If I recall correctly, it's just a series of finite field ECMUL operations over a list of EC points

author: frozenfire.eth
content: Yes, that's not necessarily bad. What matters is the complexity and cost of obtaining the entirety of the toxic waste from all contributions.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: But allow more contributions to be part of the ceremony

author: frozenfire.eth
content: If even a single person's toxic waste is destroyed and unknown, the whole setup is secure.

author: frozenfire.eth
content: What we're trying to do is increase both the likelihood that such a thing will end up being true (e.g. no universal setup client which has a compromised dependency), and create a subset of contributions which are highly transparent, such that in the future anyone could verify the likelihood that the ceremony is secure without a high degree of trust.

author: carlbeek
content:
ok, so you come up with a secret 'x'. the coordinator sends you what look like a random set of BLS points: {P, Q, R, ....}.

you multiply each point by the next power of your secret: {x.P, x^2.Q, x^3.R,...} and send that back to the coordinator. (along with some extra points as proof).

if you did something like MPC for your secret x with your friends, you'd have to perform the multiplication in MPC as well

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dankrad> We could, but:

(1) We can increase security and trust by doing an Ethereum-specific setup. Likely none of the existing ones would fully meet the Ethereum community's standards. We can run our setup so that it strictly increases existing setup's security

(2) Doing our own setup allows us to explicitly cap the monomial degrees, which obviates the need for degree proofs. So the whole thing becomes more efficient and also simpler to design (degree proofs everywhere are a PITA)
